title: Bennett Springs, Missouri
text:
Bennett Spring is an <a href="unincorporated%20area">unincorporated community</a> and <a href="census-designated%20place">census-designated place</a> (CDP) in <a href="Dallas%20County%2C%20Missouri">Dallas</a> and <a href="Laclede%20County%2C%20Missouri">Laclede</a> counties, <a href="Missouri">Missouri</a>, United States. As of the <a href="2010%20United%20States%20Census">2010 census</a> it had a population of 130. It lies west of <a href="Lebanon%2C%20Missouri">Lebanon</a> on <a href="Missouri%20Route%2064">Missouri Route 64</a>. The community is named after a <a href="spring%20%28hydrology%29">spring</a> that is reported variously as the third or fourth largest in the state, with an average daily flow of about one hundred million gallons, and which is the centerpiece of <a href="Bennett%20Spring%20State%20Park">Bennett Spring State Park</a>.
The community is located adjacent to the <a href="confluence">confluence</a> of Bennett Spring Branch with the <a href="Niangua%20River">Niangua River</a>, a north-flowing tributary of <a href="Lake%20of%20the%20Ozarks">Lake of the Ozarks</a> and part of the <a href="Osage%20River">Osage River</a> watershed, which flows northeast to the <a href="Missouri%20River">Missouri River</a>. The spring itself is located approximately one mile south along Bennett Spring Branch within the park boundaries.
Bennett Spring State Park is one of the Missouri <a href="trout">trout</a> parks. The park features the largest spring of the four parks. Trout fishing, camping, and hiking are the main activities in the park, and the park also offers <a href="cottage">cabins</a>, a <a href="swimming%20pool">swimming pool</a>, nature center, and a full-service store.
An early variant name was "Brice", after James Brice, the proprietor of a local <a href="watermill">watermill</a>. A post office called Brice was established in 1900, the name was changed to Bennett Springs in 1939, and the post office closed in 1966.
